awd_titl_txt: FRG:  Collaborative Research:  Geometric Structures on Higher Teichmuller Spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
A surface is a space which looks locally like the 2-dimensional plane, e.g. the surface of a basketball or a pretzel. Surfaces arise naturally in many scientific fields. A geometric structure is a way of measuring distances and angles on a surface or more complicated object. Studying spaces of geometric structures (or shapes) on a fixed object gives further information about their nature. The classical Teichmuller theory studies a space which parametrizes certain geometric structures (of constant curvature) on a fixed surface. Teichmuller theory has impacted diverse areas in mathematics, including algebraic geometry, complex analysis, low-dimensional topology, and dynamics, as well as theoretical physics through its connections with string theory. A metric on Teichmuller space is a way of measuring the distance, or difference, between two such geometric structures. The PIs plan to study metrics on a generalization of this theory called Higher Teichmuller Theory. Higher Teichmuller spaces may be viewed as deformation spaces of geometric structures on higher-dimensional spaces. It shares some of the nice properties of the classical theory and has become a very active field of research. The PIs will  mentor graduate students who will be engaged in aspects of the project. They will also run a program which helps science and engineering students from low-resource high schools transition to college studies.

Higher Teichmuller theory studies spaces of "geometric" representations of a hyperbolic group into a semi-simple Lie group. The main goal is to develop a theory which shares the richness, beauty and versatility of classical Teichmuller theory. The Higher theory has exploded in popularity because of the interactions it fosters between the subjects of geometric topology, real and complex differential geometry, Lie theory, algebraic geometry, string theory, and dynamics. Bridgeman, Canary, Labourie and Sambarino used thermodynamic formalism to construct a pressure metric on many higher Teichmuller spaces which is motivated by Thurston's definition of the Weil-Petersson metric on Teichmuller space (and its reformulations by Bonahon and McMullen). In the special case of the Hitchin component, the pressure metric is a mapping class group invariant, analytic Riemannian metric whose restriction to the Fuchsian locus is a multiple of the Weil-Petersson metric. Wolf developed an analogous approach to the Weil-Petersson metric, and has results on the isometry group and curvature of the Weil-Petersson metric, degeneration of hyperbolic structures, and on harmonic maps (Hitchin equations) approaches to Teichmuller theory. Wentworth has worked on the pressure metric, Weil-Petersson geometry, Higgs bundles and harmonic maps. The PIs together propose to study the isometry group, curvature and metric completion of both the pressure metric and variants on Hitchin components and quasifuchsian spaces, aiming to understand the pressure metric on general higher Teichmuller spaces.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: Prof. Canary studies deformation space of geometric structures on manifolds. Hyperbolic structures are the first natural class of non-Euclidean structures on manifolds.

In the setting of hyperbolic 3-manifolds, Prof. Canary established a Relative Bounded Image Theorem which generalizes an earlier result of Thurston. This theorem shows that the topology of a hyperbolic 3-manifold imposes strong constraints on the internal geometry of the manifold.

 

Prof. Canary also studies higher rank geometric structures. Here one of the most prominent class of examples are the Hitchin representations of closed surface groups. He generalized this theory to encompass the study of Hitchin representations of geometrically finite Fuchsian groups, establishing stability, counting and equidistribution results in this setting. He also established rigidity theorems for Hitchin representations, showing that they are determined by the lengths of simple closed curves.

 

Anosov representations are a natural common generalization of Hitchin representations and holonomy maps of hyperbolic structures. Prof. Canary showed that there are  significant restrictions on which hyperbolic groups admit certain types of Anosov representations. For example, he showed that  all torsion-free Borel Anosov groups are either surface groups or free groups.

 

Broader impact: Prof. Canary served the larger mathematical community by editing mathematical journals (Memoirs and Transactions of the American Mathematical Society and Geometriae Dedicata), organizing several conferences and  giving expository mini-courses. He published an article in the Early Career section  of the Notices of the American Mathematical Society on how to apply for a postdoctoral research assistant professorship. He also prepared and made publicly available extensive lecture notes on the theory of Anosov  representations. 

 

In his department,  Prof. Canary has supervised the postdoctoral program in the Department of Mathematics for several years. He has served on the Climate Committee, which has developed presentations for the department and produced a departmental statement on diversity. He is on the steering committee of the Inquiry Based Learning Center at Michigan and has mentored junior faculty in the use of inquiry-based methods in their own teaching practices. He has also served as a research mentor for  graduate and undergraduate students, postdoctoral assistant professors and tenure-track assistant professors.
